Jeff, I'm sure it depends on which software version of NEAT or HyperNEAT yo=
u are using.  I think my code will not mix up the order given a tie, so it =
doesn't have that nice feature implemented, but others might do something l=
ike that.

ken

>
> Out of curiosity, does anyone know how this works in NEAT/HyperNEAT at=
 the
> moment? 
> 
> How does it break ties, especially with regard to the =
generation champion
> (when elitism is on)?
> 
>

> Jeff Clune

roups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>, Colin Green

c: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>

: CfP: IEEE Symposium on Computational Intelligence and
> > Games

Quoting Colin Green <colin.green1@...>:
> > 
> >> 2009/5/25 Julian Togelius=
 <julian@...>:
> >>> 
> >>> Another example: Just last week at CEC we discu=
ssed the simple but
> >>> powerful idea that you should scramble your popul=
ation before sorting
> >>> (or use a non-order-preserving sorting algorithm=
) in a normal
> >>> Evolution Strategy to encourage exploitation of neutral=
ity in the
> >>> search space.
> >> 
> >> If I'm understanding you correctl=
y then I think the fairly standard
> >> technique (AFAIK) of roulette wheel=
 selection  effectively does this
> >> anyway.
> >> 
> >> Colin
> >> 
> > 
=
> > 
> > Roulette wheel though would be an overly aggressive non-determinis=
tic
> > selection
> > function. I think what Julian is referring to is much=
 simpler. If you have a
> > list of individuals sorted in best-first order,=
 then an order-preserving
> > sorting algorithm would prefer the older indi=
viduals over newer ones in the
> > case of a tie. I think the hypothesis he=
re is that if you have a big plateau
> > then you should randomly pick betw=
een the older/newer individuals that are
> > tying, because it allows the a=
lgorithm to spread out its search; even if it's
> > effectively doing a ran=
dom walk at that point. If the same individual keeps
> > spawning children =
each generation (assuming a Gaussian mutation with a fixed
> > sigma that's=
 small relative to the plateau) then your search will potentially
> > get s=
tuck.
> > 
> > Wesley
>
